Resume.description: Represents a resume created by a user.

templateId.description: Reference to the ResumeTemplate used for this resume. (Relationship: ResumeTemplate 1:N Resume)

title.description: Title of the resume (e.g., 'Software Engineer Resume').

createdAt.description: Timestamp indicating when the resume was created.

updatedAt.description: Timestamp indicating when the resume was last updated.

ResumeTemplate.title: ResumeTemplate
ResumeTemplate.description: Represents a template used for creating resumes.

id.description: Unique identifier for the resume template.

description.description: Description of the template's features and suitability.

imageUrl.description: URL of the template's preview image.

firestore.reasoning:
The Firestore data structure is designed to support the ResuMaster application, focusing on user profiles, resumes, and resume templates. The structure prioritizes authorization independence and simplifies security rules.

*   **User Profiles:** User profiles are stored in a dedicated collection (`/userProfiles/{userProfileId}`). This allows for easy management of user data and simplifies security rules based on user ID.
*   **Resumes:** Resumes are stored in a subcollection under each user's profile (`/userProfiles/{userProfileId}/resumes/{resumeId}`). This establishes a clear ownership hierarchy (UserProfile 1:N Resume), simplifying access control. The `userProfileId` is also included in the Resume document itself (denormalized), further supporting Authorization Independence.
*   **Resume Templates:** Resume templates are stored in a separate collection (`/resumeTemplates/{resumeTemplateId}`).  These are generally considered public/read-only data, and security rules will reflect this.

This structure achieves Authorization Independence by denormalizing the `userProfileId` into the `Resume` documents. This avoids the need for `get()` calls in security rules to verify ownership. QAPs (Rules are not Filters) are supported by the structural segregation. User-specific data is stored under the `/userProfiles/{userProfileId}` path, enabling efficient and secure `list` operations based on user ID.
